description.narrative: The Project restores and promotes sustainable livelihoods through the development of two main categories of livelihood assets at the community level.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

provider-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

description.narrative: 1.1 Percentage of households whose livelihood assets have increased 12 months from project inception (e.g. livestock, agriculture production) 1.2 Number of savings and loans associations formed and active (number of women and men participating) 1.3 Number of value chain related producer groups / Associations established / reactivated and % of women participating 1.4 % increase of net annual income achieved by producer groups and households attributable to project activities 2.1 Number of infrastructure rehabilitated/developed (by type) 2.2 Number of community members benefiting from infrastructure rehabilitated/ developed by age and sex 2.3 Percentage of rehabilitated/ developed community assets linked with markets and value chains (by type of value chain) 2.4 Number of men and women employed in temporary labour intensive schemes 2.5 Percentage of people in target areas with improved perceptions of social cohesion within twelve to eighteen months of project, disaggregated by sex and age 3.1 Number of CBRMs established that are functional 3.2 % of community members who reported decrease in natural resource related conflicts. 3.3 % community members reporting increased access to dispute resolution mechanisms 3.4 % of natural resource conflicts successfully mediated 4.1 % of recruitment of Project Management Team 4.2 Number of monitoring field visits conducted 4.3 Number of STCCs and Board meetings held

comment.narrative: 1.1 TBD 1.2 9 savings and loans associations in place 1.3 4 value chain related producer groups / Associations established/reactivated (with at least 53% women participating). 1.4 Average increase of 51.7% in annual incomes across all 4 value chains from $500 to about $758 in 2014/15 2.1 21 different infrastructure rehabilitated/developed (30% natural resource /70% socio-economic 2.2 1,000 community members benefiting from existing infrastructure 2.3 2.3 40% of rehabilitated/ developed community assets linked with markets and value chains 2.4 463 labor (52% men and 48 % women) employed in temporary labour intensive schemes 2.5 50% of people in target areas with improved perceptions of social cohesion within twelve to eighteen months of project, 20% F 3.1 27 CBRMs currently in place and functional 3.2 60% of community members stating decrease in community conflicts as a result of project in CD and SD in 2015 3.3 TBD 3.4 TBD 4.1 Programme Manager, RR Officer (NOA), 2 Programme Coordinators, Project Associate are in place 4.2 Each staff conducts average 3 monitoring field visits within a year 4.3 Average 3 STCCs and 1 board meeting held per year

1.1 75% of households reporting increase in livelihood assets in 12 months from project inception (e.g. livestock, agriculture production). 1.2 At least 3 additional associations formed and active (number of women and men participating) 2.1 At least 2 key infrastructures developed / rehabilitated (by type).

1.1 Due to support from this project, communities are now able to identify their own problems and develop plans and strategies to solve them. 1.1.1 Capacity of some 667 people (32F) in 35 communities was built through Training of Trainers (ToTs) workshops in community problem diagnosis and planning tools including the Community-based Environmental Action Planning (CEAP) and Community-based Participatory Planning (CBPP) who now lead community-based planning. 1.1.2 Field Monitoring Survey (December 2017) indicate that net annual incomes of beneficiary households have increased by up to an average of 256% from average of $758 to $1,946 per annum through improvements in production, processing, and marketing of value chain commodities. 1.1.3 Groundnuts Value Chain provided beneficiaries the highest income earning opportunity with incomes ranging from SDG 15,000 to 60,000 per year (more than the target 75%). 1.1.4 Honey Value Chain has the second highest income earning potential for the most vulnerable, especially women. The average monthly income for beekeepers increased from SDG 2000 in 2015 to about SDG3,600 in 2017. There are 3 seasons of production of about 9 months: averaging 32,400SDG per year. 1.1.5 Some 1,436-household increased access to high quality locally adapted, Open Pollinated Variety (OPV) seeds which increased their area under cultivation and increased yield by over 198%. 1.1.6 Final field monitoring survey indicated that 79% of all beneficiaries indicated an increase in both financial and non-financial assets by an average of 81% since the start of this project. An average of 46.4% of targeted women expressed an increase in decision making power within their households and within communities, groups, and associations. 1.2 The project improved community access to critical assets for over 16,000 households that enhanced productive capacities 1.2.1 Two (2) dams were rehabilitated and used for seed multiplication, where rehabilitated over 900 feddans of irrigated land was used for regular farming and dry season gardening. 1.2.2 Over 200MT of improved seed was produced from the dams over the last two years valuing nearly $500,000 which was re-circulated. 1.2.3 A number of 23 other different community assets (including hand pumps, markets, and community centers, grinding mills, gum Arabic center) were established/rehabilitated which increased access to water, markets and other services. 1.2.4 Communities indicate that the infrastructure has increased protection for women from rape and attack as they no longer go far to access certain services water, grinding mills and markets.
2. The project established of Community Development Committees (CDCs), Community Based Reconciliation Mechanisms (CBRMS). 2.1 The CDCs and CBRMs restored hope in the communities and settled disputes, thereby creating enabling environment for livelihoods activities. 2.2 According to terminal perception survey conducted in December 2017, 99% of the people in the target communities said that social cohesion has improved compared to 2015. 2.3 Some 98% of respondents’ state that they feel communal conflict has reduced compared to the per-project period 2015.
N/A. The project has no planned activities in 2019.
